resources.string: \nUncommon Coffee Roasters opened in the spring of 1994 with a goal of providing the best fresh roasted specialty coffee to our customers. We take pride in our product and expect all of our employees to do so as well. We stress education, consistency, and customer service as the three areas of focus for our baristas.\n

There is something to be said about small. After all, the best things come in small packages. At Uncommon Coffee Roasters we believe in small. We purchase our coffees from small growers in small farms or cooperatives. When possible, we travel to these farms to personally meet the farmers, ensure they are paid fairly and to guarantee the quality our customers would expect. Our coffee is always roasted in small batches to guarantee optimal quality every time we roast. \n

We source our green coffee globally, traveling to the origin whenever possible. Once our beans arrive to us, we store them in ideal conditions to guarantee the freshest coffee possible. When it comes to roasting we are proud to say that we only roast in small batches. Roasting in small batches allows us to ensure that we roast each and every batch to perfection every time we roast.\n

We proudly provide coffee to small cafes and to large corporations. We consider our wholesale customers our partners. We assist our customers in growing their coffee sales. We can provide equipment, training and consultation. Our goal is to insure that our wholesale customers provide the best product possible and the quality that they could only expect from Uncommon Coffee Roasters.\n
Find us on your favorite social media!
If you have any questions, please call us at 1-269-455-5111

For the recipes in the Coffee Wizard to be applicable, the user must pour the water as restricted and slowly as possible without letting the water stream drip. This will maximize consistency and let the grind size and coffee density determine our overall brew time. Start by pouring the water from the center out to the edge of the brewer in quick circles as to saturate all grounds evenly. Remember, we want a restricted flow, but quick circles.

Most of the brew recipes and brewers will use a similar grind size. Start by matching the grind size to the picture provided. If your coffee tastes sour or brews too quickly, adjust the grind FINER. If the the coffee tastes bitter or brews too slowly, grind the coffee COARSER. The grind size for the V60 and Press pot will be very similar for our recipes, but the chemex will use a slightly coarser grind. The grounds should feel like a medium fine table salt if run between your fingers. \n

All grinders will perform differently, even the same models will vary slightly. Successful coffee brewing comes from maximizing the uniformity (evenness) of ground coffee particles because the particle size determines how quickly the coffee will be extracted.\n

Burr Grinders - Burr grinders supply the best grind uniformity, however, flat burrs tend to do a better job than conical burrs. In addition to the burrs’ teeth shape, the size of the burrs matter too. We tend to favor larger burrs because they chop the coffee a greater number of times before the grounds exit the grinder. This means that it is more likely that the grounds will end up being the correct size.\n

Blade Grinders - Blade grinders work, but they aren’t ideal as you can’t control the particle size. Try experimenting with pulsing and shaking the grinder so that all parts of the beans are chopped. \n
Fines and boulders are what we call the extreme outliers for particles that are too big and small. These components are inevitable, but we can reduce them by changing burrs once worn down or dull.\n
We can get rid of our fines and boulders by using a few simple tricks. Ideally, we want a grind size of 400 microns, but this is hardly measurable at home without buying a sieve or expensive gear.\n
- Grind a little extra coffee and run the grounds through a fine kitchen sifter. This will catch the boulders we don’t want. Go ahead and discard them.\n
- Dump grounds onto a paper towel or a damp coffee filter and rub the coffee into the paper. The fines should stick the paper towel or filter. Throw away the paper towel when finished.\n
- Your grounds are ready to go and much more consistent than before! \n

Coffee is is about 98-99% water, it only makes sense that we need tasty water to make tasty coffee. As a general rule, if the water tastes bad, so will the coffee, but there are components to water that you may not notice that are hurting your brew quality. Optimally, we don’t want our water to taste like anything, but that’s not to say we want our water distilled. We do NEED minerals in our water for us extract our coffee properly, but in order to protect our equipment and maximize taste we want to keep the minerals to a minimum. Water as soft as 80ppm can taste great, as well as coffees up to 140ppm. Ideally, we want our minerals to be magnesium and calcium as they are some of the biggest flavor extractors of coffee. We want to avoid, salts, chlorine, fluoride, etc. We recommend a Reverse Osmosis system with the option to blend in hard water. We understand that this is probably not accessible in the kitchen. If not, we recommend using a normal pitcher filter (like britta), and blending that with anywhere from 30-50% distilled water. Experiment to find where your water tastes best! \n

To find the density of your coffee, you can either take a bite out of a roasted bean, or you can try to crush it in your fingers. The lower the density, the easier it will be to break. If if feels like you are eating potato chips, it is most likely low density. If if feels like you are eating a soft marble, it will most likely be high density. As a rule of thumb, a light roast will mean the coffee is high density, and a Dark roast is low density. If your coffee brewed radically too fast or slow, try selecting a different density.\n

In the ‘Dial-In’ option in the Coffee Wizard, we ask you to choose a low, medium, or high density options for the coffee. This refers to the bean density of the coffee. Depending on how the coffee was roasted in addition to its green qualities, each coffee with have a unique amount of moisture and density of organic matter. We gave you three options that should get you in the ballpark of your target brew time. The denser a coffee, the longer it takes for water to penetrate the grounds. This means that the highest density coffees will flow slower, and will take longer to extract. Likewise, the lowest density coffees will brew much easier and quickly.\n
Rate Us on the Play Store!
